comments.commentBody: Thank you for this interesting article.  Interestingly, the behavior modification component helps folks across the range of ages - in my 40s, it taught me how to change my thinking and therefore my feeling. Kaiser, on the west coast, makes CBT cost effective and nothing but helpful.

To RS: Why bother to have elections? Simply turn over the function of government to corporations with rich stockholders and change rules by fiat. Then you might like to tear up the Constitution and the Bill of Rights and have what government is left issue each citizen guns and ammunition. Privatize education, eliminate government oversight and pay teachers minimum wage plus 10% for each student they push through to the next grade.
That is not the country I signed up to live in 80 years ago. Maybe you need to grow up to achieve some wisdom.

With the Trump Reign stressing the atomic weapons need of a weakened and vulnerable America;
followed by exemptions and repeal of environmental regulations for defense programs;
and limited Federal safety monitoring by the Department of Energy and the Commerce Department;
a system explosion at a nuclear weapons assembly site has released several tons of radioactive material in the Pacific Northwest.

Asked about the situation,
Secretary of the Energy Department, Rick Perry responded:

oooooooooooooopppppppps

Elizabeth, I agree with you that Steve Bannon is at the root of these destructive choices. In fact, I strongly suspect Trump couldn't even name one of "his" nominees without mismatching the nominee with an agency or department.
This is deeply troubling to me--to us all of course---because I don't think the goal is allowing private business [and bankers] to sweep in for the kill. They've already swept.
Please forgive me if I sound like a fruitcake when I suggest this is an attack on our nation as a whole. Think what the U.S. would be if everyone of these nominees is permitted to follow their "dream" of destroying their least favorite agency or department from within.
Yes, sure, Putin or some other foreign actor might be behind this. Or just Bannon.
Let's go back a few years instead to Grover Norquist browbeating GOP candidates into signing his document pledging no new taxes. What was Norquist's next step? Making the federal gov't "small enough that it could be drowned in a bathtub."
Remember, Trump thinks MORE nations should procure nuclear weapons.
We're beyond obstruction, well into a dismantling ending in no walking back destruction.
Rick Perry flew airplanes. Airplanes drop bombs. Some bombs are nuclear. In the Trumpiverse, that qualifies Rick Perry for DOE.

Paula

Lots of women look good long after they're teenagers.

I get the feeling Trump is not doing any vetting. He talks with candidates, floats their name in the press to see any initial reactions, and if his gut tells him to he goes ahead and hires the person.

Congress will have to vet these clowns. It seems, given the information on Putin's interference, some Republican Senators have started to understand just how stupid and shallow Trump is. Those two chacteristics alone make Trump dangerous, but they seem to be his best qualities.

I cannot remember another "transition team” where the whole affair looked like a combination of Hollywood screen tests and perp walks.

Try for just a little dignity, Mr Trump. I don't remember the press camped outside Bill Clinton's transition team's offices, and I'd have tripped over them if they were there. Like regular folks in New York, we ignore such folks until they get in the way, then we walk over them. The Secret Service doesn't protect the paparazzi.

Move to DC, where you and your cronies can be safely nursemaided by the Secret Service. We don't particularly want you here, but there are mechanisms in place to protect both dignitaries and low-class politicians. This is NOT an invitation for you to bring Rudy Giuliani and Chris Christie to DC. We've put up with J Edgar, LBJ, Nixon and his band of thugs, the Bushes, even Mayor-for-Life Marion Barry, but we must draw the line somewhere.

A few harmful inaccuracies about your post.

Training to muscular failure does not obligate bad technique or form, like you implied. There's no evidence that shows the former must lead to the latter. This is a sloppy statement.

The use of the word "functional training" is vague at best, and at worst setting a premise that training a muscle in isolation is somehow dysfunctional. In many people and for many reasons, training with machines or isolating body parts is the safest option to increase muscular strength, hypertrophy and cellular metabolism as a critical factor in improvement of sugar and lipid metabolism and insulin sensitivity.

Your experiences hardly make for proof and makes for an unscientific statement. There are too many variables in training that makes it unsafe, such as improperly managed progression, volume and frequency.

Training for more muscle mass, which is one of the strongest independent predictors of all-cause mortality, and which is a direct constituent to greater number of mitochondrial growth, is in itself highly functional for humans.
Beats a cabinet full of academics and career bureaucrats any day.
That is the very least of what he has done.  If the news media would actually report on relevant information, people might be informed. And we would't have a president Trump.

It is these types of stories that helped give the impetus for us in NY to seek to become licensed Sleep Techs. Over the decade long struggle we were able to achieve this milestone, which provides a state license/registry for anyone wishing to perform ANY test dealing with a sleep disorder. YES, that includes Home Sleep Testing.
So, it is NOT OK to just pick up an HST from an office worker in a doctor's office. YOU, Mr. Ms. NY Citizen have the right to be educated and instructed by a qualified professional (Doc, Nurse, RT or Sleep tech) who can explain the issues regarding the test and the disorder. These mail order (or as I call them, Helicopter testing) are the rage, as they take almost zero start-up costs and have little operating overhead. Of course there will be charlatans. I remember seeing a magazine ad touting that for just $6000 a company could set anyone up to provide HST (Home Sleep Testing) with no background checks.
As the article mentioned, but not many practitioners follow, the simultaneous disorders (comorbidities) that should keep you from using HST is long, and as another poster mentions, the field recognizes that only people with a HIGH-LIKELIHOOD of having sleep apnea typically should be tested using HST.
I think we will be in for a more tumultuous time for our healthcare provisioning as Precedent trump repeals the ACA and puts a much more costlier and rapacious "free-market" based healthcare construct in place. Hold onto your wallets.

As a teenager I've experienced lack of sleep due to not getting enough sleep at night and the amount oh school work assigned. How do fewer amounts of sleep affect the teenage brain? I ask this question because 56% of teens feel stressed and anxious due to lack of sleep and that's not good for the brain. It is known to cause sleep deprivation and other serious health problems.

The only time I have ever had the flu is when I took a flu shott years ago. I have not had a flu shot in years. I'm 64 and my doctors say every year I must get a flu shot. They also prescribe medicine with horrible and deadly side effects. I ignor their request and refuse their medicine. I think the American people are being exploited and a lot of money is being made. Approximately $20 from every American, you do the math!!!    Bill Austin

Clyde,

What a difference a few decades make! In the late '40s and early '50s Russian "influence" in the U.S. Government was denied by the American Left and those trying to expose its extent were subject to personal distraction.

Today it's the same Left that is playing the "Senator Joe" card! "Have you no shame Sir?"
here's one lesson ... the Electoral college... or not aaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhhhh

Right, and we've been living with that corruption and incompetence for far too long.
Thank you wikileaks, Russia or whoever

In contrast to this comment, I think that Russian influence could EASILY have been a deciding factor in the election.  After all, one just needed to persuade about 100,000 people in well chosen states to believe in nutty things like Pizzagate.  As was seen in DC this week, such people are around.  And no, many of them seem quite unable to distinguish fact from fiction.
He who laughs last, laughs best.  It ain't over yet (not talking about the Electoral College).  Trump will carry the stench of this with him every single day and will never be a successful President.

Perhaps this attack on the very foundation of our democracy will teach liberals/progressives that the whole "dark web" of propaganda, foolishness, and actual leaked classified information provided by the likes of Julian Assange and Edward Snowden is (shockingly!) quite dangerous and at odds with an open liberal democracy.

And I am not a conservative, but a quite proud liberal. And yet, my compatriots are still on the fence over whether anti-American fake news / propaganda is a threat to our way of life. Whether Mr. Trump had an active or passive role in the transfer of Russian-gained information on the Dems to WikiLeaks, he has shown himself to be amoral to the greater issue of whether the USA stands up to Russia on the basic matter of freedom for Eastern Europeans.

Wikileaks don't hack people, they just publish the results. Unfortunately Assange is no friend of the USA. What the US govt needs to do is get busy hacking the Russians to find Putin's dirty secrets and send the results to the NYT or someone of similar repute to publish. Whilst simultaneously ensuring this cannot happen again.
Im a liberal, and completely agree with you. I never had sympathy for Snowden or Assange. I think there are plenty of liberals (President Obama included) are on your side on this one.

Yeah, okay, they took us for suckers, "us" meaning the media audiences that couldn't resist dishing more dirt. Shoot at us, and we'll shoot back 10x more, but trick us with our own gullibility...? Then what?

As I recall, Ben Franklin was reported to have said after the Constitutional Convention about whether we would have a monarchy or a republic: "...a Republic, if [we] can keep it."
Jonr, I was just speaking to the point of the released DNC emails.
Maybe incompetence instead of dishonesty.

If hackers manipulated a pilot to crash his aircraft, you would be rightfully incensed. But an election is manipulated to make Trump the Republican nominee and ultimately the president, against the popular will of the people, and you are "okay" with it because your horse is in the winner circle?

We are now lead by an unbalanced incompetent demonstrably weakening the security and safety of this nation.

YOU sir, are more dangerous to democracy than the Russians!
